simplify: line/polygon simplification algorithms

Detailed Description

The simplify algorithm implements the Douglas Peucker algorithm (or another simplification algorithm) to simplify linestrings. It is implemented for linestrings, multi_linestrings, linear rings, polygons and multi_polygons. Note, however, that simplifying a valid simple polygon (which never intersects itself) might result in an invalid polygon, where the simplified rings intersect themselves or one of the other outer or inner rings.

)

Simplify a polygon.

This version of simplify simplifies a polygon, using the default strategy (Douglas Peucker)

Parameters:
poly_in input polygon, to be simplified
poly_out output polygon, simplified version of the input polygon
max_distance distance (in units of input coordinates) of a vertex to other segments to be removed

Simplify a polygon.

This version of simplify simplifies a polygon, a strategy can be specified

Parameters:
poly_in input polygon, to be simplified
poly_out output polygon, simplified version of the input polygon
max_distance distance (in units of input coordinates) of a vertex to other segments to be removed
strategy simplify strategy to be used for simplification, might include point-distance strategy

)

Simplify an iterator pair.

This version of simplify uses an iterator pair, an output iterator and a distance, and simplifies using the default strategy (Douglas Peucker)

Parameters:
begin iterator pointed at first element to be simplified
end iterator pointed after last element to be simplified
out output iterator, outputs all simplified points
max_distance distance (in units of input coordinates) of a vertex to other segments to be removed

template<typename IT , typename O_IT , typename S >
void geometry::simplify ( IT  begin,
IT  end,
O_IT  out,
double  max_distance,
const S &  strategy 
)

Simplify an iterator pair.

The simplify algorithm removes points, keeping the shape as much as possible. This version of simplify is the most basic version, working on an iterator pair, an output iterator and two strategies to be specified.

Parameters:
begin iterator pointed at first element to be simplified
end iterator pointed after last element to be simplified
out output iterator, outputs all simplified points
max_distance distance (in units of input coordinates) of a vertex to other segments to be removed
strategy simplify strategy to be used for simplification, might include point-distance strategy
Example:
The simplify algorithm can be used as following: 
{
        typedef geometry::point_xy<double> P;
        typedef std::ostream_iterator<P> OUT;
        typedef geometry::strategy::distance::xy_point_segment<P> DS;
        typedef geometry::linestring<P> L;
        L line;
        geometry::from_wkt("linestring(1.1 1.1, 2.5 2.1, 3.1 3.1, 4.9 1.1, 3.1 1.9)", line);
        geometry::strategy::simplify::douglas_peucker<L::const_iterator, OUT, DS> simplification;
        geometry::simplify(line.begin(), line.end(), OUT(std::cout, "\n"), 0.5, simplification);
}
or, using a std::vector instead of a linestring, as following: 
{
        typedef geometry::point_xy<double> P;
        typedef std::ostream_iterator<P> OUT;
        typedef geometry::strategy::distance::xy_point_segment<P> DS;
        std::vector<P> line;
        geometry::from_wkt<P>("linestring(1.1 1.1, 2.5 2.1, 3.1 3.1, 4.9 1.1, 3.1 1.9)", std::back_inserter(line));
        geometry::strategy::simplify::douglas_peucker<std::vector<P>::const_iterator, OUT, DS> simplification;
        geometry::simplify(line.begin(), line.end(), OUT(std::cout, "\n"), 0.5, simplification);
}
Examples:
3_linestring_example.cpp.
